article.description: Rashad Anderson scored 21 points and a made key block in the closing seconds, leading Connecticut to an 81-76 win over Villanova on Wednesday night.
article.headline: Huskies snap out of funk against ranked opponents
article.linkText: No. 20 UConn derails Villanova in second half
article.story: HARTFORD, Conn. (AP) -- After ending Villanova's three-game winning streak, Connecticut hopes to get on a roll of its own by sharing the ball. Rashad Anderson scored 21 points and a made key block in the closing seconds to give the Huskies (No. 20 ESPN/USA Today, No. 23 AP) an 81-76 win Wednesday night, their first over a ranked opponent in four tries. "We just run our offense and you see the results," Anderson said. "Making that extra pass, it paid off tonight." The Huskies (13-5, 5-3 Big East) had 18 assists on 22 field goals and shot 74 percent in the second half to rally from seven points down. UConn's big frontcourt capitalized on physical inside play -- the Huskies made a season-high 30 free throws. Hilton Armstrong, a 6-foot-11 forward, grabbed a team-high 10 rebounds for the defending national champions in the 1,000th game of coach Jim Calhoun's career. "At times they gave us fits," Calhoun said. "Our goal was to use the size that we had. Villanova is a terrific team. They're going to be a tough out for any team that plays them." The No. 25/No. 24 Wildcats (12-5, 4-4) were on a run that included an 83-62 upset of then-No. 2 Kansas. The Huskies, who lost two of three coming into the game, took this one down to the wire. Charlie Villanueva's free throw with 1:22 left put the Huskies up 73-72. Anderson blocked a shot in the lane by Randy Foye on the Wildcats' next possession. That led to Villanueva's hook shot on the other end and a 75-72 UConn lead. Villanova coach Jay Wright was called for a technical after the basket, and Anderson went back to the line and made both free throws to ice the game. Wright grabbed referee Doug Shows to argue a point and was hit with the penalty. "I shouldn't have put our team in that position," Wright said. "I just feel bad for my players because they played so hard. I take responsibility for it." Mike Nardi scored a season-high 20 points for Villanova as the Wildcats' three-guard lineup gave UConn all it could handle. Nardi had a career-high six 3-pointers. Allan Ray added 16 and Foye finished with 15. They combined for 11 assists and five steals. Rudy Gay had 17 points for UConn, and Marcus Williams finished with 12 points and nine assists. Josh Boone scored six of his eight points from the line, and Anderson had nine of his points from line. Villanova trailed most of the first half but didn't need much time to catch up. Down by seven with just under six minutes to play, the Wildcats went on a tear, hitting four straight 3-pointers in a 14-0 run. Nardi had two 3s in the three-minute spurt and the Wildcats grabbed a 38-31 lead. The Huskies had more turnovers (10) than they did field goals (eight) in the half, but managed to cut into the deficit with a 7-2 run in the closing seconds and trailed 40-38 at halftime. "We played like our lives were on the line," Boone said. "Every game is a battle inside. That's just the nature of the Big East." And Calhoun has seen some classic Big East battles over the years. His 33-year career includes his first 14 at Northeastern and the last 19 at UConn, where he's built the program into a Big East and national powerhouse and has two NCAA titles. "To coach 1,000 games in Division I basketball is a journey I feel incredibly fortunate to experience," Calhoun said. "The people I've met, the people I've competed against and the players I've competed against and most importantly the kids I've coached and the coaches I've coached with -- those things are special to me."

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
